citation.article-title: A novel psychrophilic methanotroph of the genus Methylobacter.

p.s: Description of Methylobacter psychrophilus sp. nov.
Methylobacter psychrophilus (psy.chro.phi'lus. Gr. n. psychros, cold; Gr. adj. philus, liking; psychrophilus, liking cold)
Cells are nonmotile cocci or diplococci 1.0-1.7 μm in diameter; they possess a thin capsule and ICM of type I.
Reproduction occurs by binary fission.
Gas vesicles can be formed inside cells; the percentage of vesicle-containing cells increases with the cultivation temperature.
The vesicles are cigar-shaped, 80-110 nm wide, and up to 300 nm long.
Colonies are cream, opaque, round, and convex; they have an even edge, a smooth bright surface, and an aqueous consistency.
No water-soluble pigments are produced.
Good growth occurs at temperatures between 3.5 and 10°C.
The minimal and maximal temperatures for growth are 1°C (or lower) and 20°C, respectively.
The optimum pH is 6.8-7.2.
Strictly aerobic, obligately methanotrophic, utilizes methane and methanol as carbon and energy sources, and can grow in media with low methanol concentrations (0.05-0.1 %).
Prevalent fatty acids are C16:1.
A low content of saturated fatty acids C14:0 and C16:0 is characteristic of the composition of membrane phospholipids.
Assimilation of C1-compounds occurs via the ribulose monophosphate pathway.
The tricarboxylic acid cycle is disconnected at the level of α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase.
Isocitrate dehydrogenase is NAD-specific.
The G+C content in DNA is 45.6 mol % (Tm).
The genome size is 2.9 x 109 Da.
One plasmid is present.
Inhabits swampy tundra soil.
The type strain Z-0021 is stored at the Institute of Microbiology, Russian Academy of Sciences, and has been deposited with the All-Russia Collection of Microorganisms as VKM B-2103.
